06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The 49th year after Aegon’s Conquest gave the people of Westeros a welcome respite from the chaos and conflict that had gone before. It would be a year of peace, plenty, and marriage, remembered in the annals of the Seven Kingdoms as the Year of the Three Brides.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The Year of the Three Brides was an iconic time in Westeros, as it marked the start of Aegon's conquest. His arrival was welcomed with plenty of celebration and optimism as people anticipated what this new era would bring. Little did they know that not long after would come Maegor the Cruel and his men to terrorize townsfolk across Westeros. Yet despite all his attempts, Aegon's rule has given much more than it ever took away - many are grateful for his willingness to give them a better future in light of all he had gone through himself.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The new year was but a fortnight old when news of the first of the three weddings came out of the west, from Fair Isle by the Sunset Sea. There, in a small swift ceremony under the sky, Rhaena Targaryen wed Androw Farman, the second son of the Lord of Fair Isle. It was the groom’s first marriage, the bride’s third. Though twice widowed, Rhaena was but twenty-six. Her new husband, just ten-and-seven, was notably younger, a comely and amiable youth said to be utterly besotted with his new wife.
places: Fair Isle by the Sunset Sea
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The wedding of Rhaena Targaryen and Androw Farman at Fair Isle by the Sunset Sea was nothing short of spectacular. Throughout Westeros, they were heralded as the most besotted couple to become wed in recent years – the swiftness with which their union was decided became a thing of legend. The amiable couple had soon gained fame for being both comely and charismatic, and news of their nuptials reached all corners of the realm. Even Hand Samgood of Sour Hill arrived at the ceremony to give his blessing, along with Dowager Queen Morton Caron who brought plenty gifts for her young granddaughter-in-law. Alyn Royce, Lord Vance’s son, even saw fit to accompany them – though hardly any knew just why he felt so welcomed.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Their wedding was presided over by the groom’s father, Marq Farman, Lord of Fair Isle, and conducted by his own septon. Lyman Lannister, Lord of Casterly Rock, and his wife, Jocasta, were the only great lords in attendance. Two of Rhaena’s former favorites, Samantha Stokeworth and Alayne Royce, made their way to Fair Isle in some haste to stand with the widowed queen, together with the groom’s high-spirited sister, the Lady Elissa. The remainder of the guests were bannermen and household knights sworn to either House Farman or House Lannister. King and court remained entirely ignorant of the marriage until a raven from the Rock brought word, days after the wedding feast and the bedding that sealed the match.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The festivities of Rhaena Targaryen's and Androw Farman's wedding were still resounding on Fair Isle by the Sunset Sea. On this day, all eyes were riveted on Marq Farman as he presided over the bedding ceremony. After conducting the ritual, Lord Lyman Lannister smiled at his newly made son-in-law and gave him a hearty pat on his back. Also in attendance amongst the hale was Jocasta, Samantha Stokeworth, Lady Elissa Royce, Lady Alayne among many others. As their eyes shone bright with happiness for the bride and groom, they broke into yet another cheer that echoed throughout Casterly Rock.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Chroniclers in King’s Landing report that Queen Alyssa was deeply offended by her exclusion from her daughter’s wedding, and that relations between mother and child were never as warm afterward, whereas Lord Rogar Baratheon was furious that Rhaena had dared remarry without the Crown’s leave…the Crown in this instance being himself, as the young king’s Hand. Had leave been asked, however, there was no certainty it would have been granted, for Androw Farman, the second son of a minor lord, was thought by many to be far from worthy of the hand of a woman who had been twice a queen and remained the mother of the king’s heir. (As it happened, the youngest of Lord Rogar’s brothers remained unwed as of 49 AC, and his lordship had two nephews by another brother who were also of a suitable age and lineage to be considered potential mates for a Targaryen widow, facts which might well explain both the Hand’s anger and the secrecy with which Queen Rhaena wed.) King Jaehaerys himself and his sister Alysanne rejoiced at the tidings, dispatching gifts and congratulations to Fair Isle and commanding that the Red Keep’s bells be rung in celebration.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa and Lord Rogar Baratheon presided over the joyous occasion of Queen Rhaena wed to King Jaehaerys's son Androw Farman at Kings Landing. The daughter’s wedding was attended by Lady Elissa and her husband, along with Alysanne Targaryen and many others from Fair Isle to Casterly Rock. They reported that the young bride rejoiced when she remarried! As word spread, cheers echoed through King’s Landing, the Red Keep, Fair Isle and beyond as people praised their queen and rejoiced in reuniting lost families. Almost forgotten were rumours of an imminent threat – Daemon Velaryon had been spotted at the Tides encroaching upon Tyrosh – but on this blissful day, people forgot even their enemies.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Whilst Rhaena Targaryen was celebrating her marriage on Fair Isle, back in King’s Landing King Jaehaerys and his mother, the Queen Regent, were busy selecting the councillors who would help them rule the realm for the next two years. Conciliation remained their guiding principle, for the divisions that had so recently torn Westeros apart were far from healed. Rewarding his own loyalists and excluding Maegor’s men and the Faithful from power would only exacerbate the wounds and give rise to new grievances, the young king reasoned. His mother agreed.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Queen Rhaena Targaryen, accompanied by King Jaehaerys and the Queen Regent, had set out for Fair Isle to celebrate a marriage. Upon arriving at King's Landing, they sought out the counsel of Lord Rogar Baratheon who was deciding upon whom the queen should select to rule under her while she remained on Fair Isle. Lord Rogar thoughtfully considered each candidate before rewarding Alyn Royce with the position as Hand and excluding Walton Corbray; his reasoning unknown even to herself. There were great rejoicings throughout the Lands, especially in regards to news of house Targaryen following their daughter’s wedding when Queen Rhaena wed Androw Farman from House Farman of Fair Isle where cakes sweetly blessed by priests were shared amongst all celebrating the union between their two houses - lords, ladies and common folk alike.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Accordingly, Jaehaerys reached out to the Lord of Claw Isle, Edwell Celtigar, who had been Hand of the King under Maegor, and recalled him to King’s Landing to serve as lord treasurer and master of coin. For lord admiral and master of ships, the young king turned to his uncle Daemon Velaryon, Lord of the Tides, Queen Alyssa’s brother and one of the first great lords to abandon Maegor the Cruel. Prentys Tully, Lord of Riverrun, was summoned to court to serve as master of laws; with him came his redoubtable wife, the Lady Lucinda, far famed for her piety. Command of the City Watch, the largest armed force in King’s Landing, the king entrusted to Qarl Corbray, Lord of Heart’s Home, who had fought beside Aegon the Uncrowned beneath the Gods Eye. Above them all stood Rogar Baratheon, Lord of Storm’s End and Hand of the King.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: As King Jaehaerys reached out to his faithful servants he recalled Edwell Celtigar and Daemon Velaryon, who he had entrusted many years ago. Turning to Prentys Tully, Lady Lucinda and Qarl Corbray, the King summoned them all to court with the promise of rewarding their loyalty. His young spirit was greatly lifted when they all arrived in King's Landing from as far away as Claw Isle, the Tides and Riverrun. Feeling more confident than ever before he also recalled Rogar Baratheon from Storm’s End – a Great Lord whose loyalty and service had remained unwavering for years after excluding him from selecting who would rule next in his own House.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: It would be a mistake to underestimate the influence of Jaehaerys Targaryen himself during the years of his regency, for despite his youth the boy king had a seat at most every council (but not all, as will be told shortly) and was never shy about letting his voice be heard. In the end, however, the final authority throughout this period rested with his mother, the Queen Regent, and the Hand, a redoubtable man in his own right.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys Targaryen, the boy king, was not likely to be underestimated. He had a restful youth and by the time he announced his regency of the realm, very few people were prepared for what he could bring to the table. Despite some initial doubts about his capabilities due to his young age, Jaehaerys proved himself to be a redoubtable ruler – even when faced with difficult decisions such as dispatching Lord Rogar Baratheon of Storm’s End to Eastwatch-by-the-Sea in order to oppose Queen Regent Alyssa's Golden Wedding decree.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Blue-eyed and black-bearded and muscled like a bull, Lord Rogar was the eldest of five brothers, all grandsons of Orys One-Hand, the first Baratheon Lord of Storm’s End. Orys had been a bastard brother to Aegon the Conqueror and his most trusted commander. After slaying Argilac the Arrogant, last of the Durrandon, he had taken Argilac’s daughter to wife. Lord Rogar could thus claim that both the blood of the dragon and that of the storm kings of old flowed in his veins. No swordsman, his lordship preferred to wield a double-bladed axe in battle…an axe, he oft said, “large and heavy enough to cleave through a dragon’s skull.”
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar Baratheon of Storm's End was an intimidating figure - a blue-eyed, black-bearded behemoth of a man who could cleave any foe with his wield of the sword. He personally killed Argilac the Arrogant in single combat, earning him respect and reverence from Aegon the Conqueror to Orys One-Hand. But none anticipated he would one day play such an essential role in restoring House Targaryen to its former glory when Lord Rogar chose to accompany young Jaehaerys Targaryen after the boy king had been underestimated by his enemies. The redoubtable Lord Rogar put aside his own ambitions and rode to King's Landing alongside Prince Aegon and Princess Rhaenys while wielding nothing but a word as he passed through great gates of dragons, ensuring that all seven kingdoms rested on solid ground beneath young King Jaehaerys’s feet and never again would underestimate one so youthful graced with ancient memory and strong leadership.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Those were dangerous words during the reign of Maegor the Cruel, but if Rogar Baratheon feared Maegor’s wroth, he hid it well. Men who knew him were unsurprised when he gave shelter to Queen Alyssa and her children after their flight from King’s Landing, and when he was the first to proclaim Prince Jaehaerys king. His own brother Borys was heard to say that Rogar dreamed of facing King Maegor in single combat and cutting him down with his axe.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Maegor the Cruel had quickly earned notoriety for his cruel and ruthless nature, and so it came as no surprise to King's Landing that he would be proclaimed Lord of Storm's End by Jaehaerys himself. Borys, Alyssa's eldest son whom she had dreamed of having become Hand one day, watched with a heavy heart on. He knew the dangerous reputation Maegor carried with him, and feared what he might do if given such powers. His uncle Rogar Baratheon did not seem unsurprised at his proclamation, though cuttingly gathering that Maegor was well suited to wielding the castle further strengthened Borys' unease. As the citizens muttered among themselves in fear of their new lord, little did they know what was truly in store for them - danger looming well beyond their wildest dreams.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: That dream fate denied him. Instead of a kingslayer, Lord Rogar became a kingmaker, delivering to Prince Jaehaerys the Iron Throne. Few questioned his right to take his place at the side of the young king as Hand; some went so far as to whisper that it would be Rogar Baratheon who ruled the realm henceforth, for Jaehaerys was a boy and the son of a weak father, whilst his mother was only a woman. And when it was announced that Lord Rogar and Queen Alyssa were to marry, the whispers grew louder…for what is a queen’s lord husband, if not a king?
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar was the first to answer call of the Kingmaker and had taken his place on the Iron Throne. Whispering that young, weak Jaehaerys should be married off as soon as possible, he made sure no one in King's Landing was unsurprised by Lord Darry's sudden announcement about young couple's wedding. As Lord Rogar delivered his decree, Queen Alyssa of House Targaryen well understood how dangerous a game they were facing, silently cutting away from Maegor the Cruel’s threat which she had feared ever since it was proclaimed in her father’s castle gates. While the situation might have felt dire for some, she dreamed what wonders their marriage would bring to Westeros - although Maegor wasn't happy with these results and after seeing this turn of events unfold before him, he remained unsuprised as well.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Lord Rogar had been married once before, but his wife had died young, taken off by a fever less than a year after their wedding. The Queen Regent Alyssa was forty-two years old, and thought to be past her child-bearing years; the Lord of Storm’s End, ten years her junior. Writing some years later, Septon Barth tells us that Jaehaerys was opposed to the marriage; the young king felt that his Hand was overreaching himself, motivated more by a desire for power and position than a true affection for his mother. He was angry that neither his mother nor her suitor had sought his leave as well, Barth said…but as he had raised no objections to his sister’s marriage, the king did not believe he had the right to prevent his mother’s. Jaehaerys thus held his tongue and gave no hint of his misgivings save to a few close confidants.
adjectives: motivated more by a desire for power and position than a true affection for his mother
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar and Queen Regent Alyssa had been married for almost forty-two years when tragedy struck: Prince Jaehaerys took ill from a fever, preventing his mother from delivering an heir to the Iron Throne. House Baratheon was writing its own history in turbulence as Lord Rogar Baratheon sought to raise himself above his rightful place and overreaching himself motivated more by a desire for power and position than a true affection for his mother. Septon Barth was held up as the solution; he gave young Jaehaerys, past her child-bearing years, away in marriage to Lord of Storm’s End hoping that would be enough to prevent her son from claiming what she considered hers. The Seven Kingdoms were on edge with news of this unexpected union; rumours whispering about enemies Qarl Corbray had made through his alliances with Hand Samantha Stokeworth spread throughout Westeros like wildfire.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The Hand was admired for his courage, respected for his strength, feared for his military prowess and skill at arms. The Queen Regent was loved. So beautiful, so brave, so tragic, women said of her. Even such lords as might have balked at a woman ruling over them were willing to accept her as their liege, secure in the knowledge that she had Rogar Baratheon standing beside her, and the young king less than a year away from his sixteenth nameday.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The Hand, admired and loved by the Queen Regent and Rogar Baratheon alike, were willing to follow them anywhere. They praised his courage as well as his strong military prowess and skillful strategy. The handsome soldier was also beautiful, brave and heroic - though it was a tragedy that none of these attributes could save him from the fever that had taken him off too soon. Writing letters back home to the family he had sought to raise up with his own two hands, the young Lord of Storm's End prevented his kin from overreaching himself in what some believe was motivated more by a desire for power and position than a true affection for his mother who at forty-two years old without children past her child-bearing years.  Meanwhile despite being weakened by illness due to lack of support from her enemies in King’s Landing and House Royce, Sea Dragon Tower remained resolute under the leadership of Lady Elissa Silverwing , an advisor of Queen Alyssa who provided much needed strength to her husband Lord Rogar Baratheon during those difficult times.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: She had been a beautiful child, all men agreed, the daughter of the mighty Aethan Velaryon, Lord of the Tides, and his lady wife Alarra of House Massey. Her line was ancient, proud, and rich, her mother esteemed as a great beauty, her grandsire amongst the oldest and closest friends of Aegon the Dragon and his queens. The gods blessed Alyssa herself with the deep purple eyes and shining silvery hair of Old Valyria, and gave her charm and wit and kindness as well, and as she grew suitors flocked around her from every corner of the realm. There was never any true question of whom she would wed, however. For a girl such as her, only royalty would suffice, and in the year 22 AC she married Prince Aenys Targaryen, the unquestioned heir to the Iron Throne.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Aethan Velaryon and Alarra Massey were soon to be wed, and people from Tides and Valyria flocked to the ceremony. Alyssa was renowned for her beauty, but it was Aegon the Dragon who drew the most admiration. His eldest son, Prince Aenys Targaryen was esteemed as one of the mightiest men in Westeros according to Qarl Corbray's close observation for his great knowledge about battles since he belonged to one of the oldest families that had closest ties with House That Kingsguard members. Despite his deep shining eyes, Aenys never underestimated his enemies which made him even more beautiful than brave heroes like Rogar Baratheon and Walton who were admired for their military prowess, skillful strategies and courage in winning wars or confronting disastrous events like The Golden Wedding or Maegor's cruelty with all The Hand as a brave leader which inspired others who were willing to follow them through any kinds of tragic challenges.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Theirs was a happy and fruitful marriage. Prince Aenys was a gentle and attentive husband, warm-natured, generous, and never unfaithful. Alyssa bore him five strong, healthy children, two daughters and three sons (a sixth child, another daughter, died in her cradle shortly after birth), and when his sire died in 37 AC, the crown passed to Aenys, and Alyssa became his queen.
events: died in her cradle shortly after birth
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Prince Aenys and Alyssa were wed in a beautiful ceremony at Tides and all around them feasted and flocked, as they both were largely esteemed. The Targaryens had blessed a happy and fruitful union between the two; Prince Aenys was warm-natured, generous, strong and healthy whilst Alyssa was gentle, attentive and had a sunny disposition. But their joy was short lived when not even one month later, their daughter died in her cradle shortly after birth. Nearby in Valyria, Lord Walton Qarl Corbray of House Velaryon bade his own youngest daughter named Aerea goodbye as she voyageed to Westeros with Lord Darry Hand - Samantha Stokeworth who His Grace had engaged to be his wife’s companion on the journey. Despite the sadness of devastation for Princess Rhaenys’s passing for which Dowager Queen Elinor knew too well the pain of losing an oldest child closest in her heart from deep within her shining tears, something uplifting still bloomed knowing that Oswyck the Drunken Knight kept true faith even up until Prince Aegon’s Golden Wedding to Tarly's Lady Lucinda near King's Landing months later.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: In the years that followed, she saw her husband’s reign crumble and turn to ash, as enemies rose up all around him. In 42 AC he died, a broken man and despised, only five-and-thirty years of age. The queen scarce had time to grieve for him before his brother seized the throne that rightly belonged to her eldest son. She saw her son rise up against his uncle and die, together with his dragon. A short while later, her second son followed him to the funeral pyre, tortured to death by Tyanna of the Tower. Together with her two youngest children, Alyssa was made a prisoner in all but name of the man who had brought about the death of her sons, and was made to bear witness when her eldest daughter was forced into marriage to that same monster.
events: the reign crumble and turn to ash
came to the funeral pyre torture to death by Tyanna of the tower
forced into marriage to that same monster
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: She saw her husband's enemies rise up as soon as he died, and they seized him, made him a prisoner and followed after. The reign crumbled and turned to ash five-and-thirty years of age. With her eldest son dead in his cradle shortly after birth, the queen had no choice but to force into marriage Tyanna of the Tower - that same monster who she barely knew. Alyssa endured cruel torture by Tyanna at the funerary pyre until she broke down and agreed to marry him. As sorrow filled all around him Aenys could do nothing but watch his beloved mother succumb to pressure from their enemies outside of Westeros as she gracious bowed out for that same monster as her second son's bride. Little did Aenys know that this event would be just one mere puzzle piece in a long line of events leading to what would later become known as 'The Golden Wedding' – where Targaryens were broken under Maegor the Cruel’s rule by His High Holiness culminating in an arrest warrant served on Queen Regent Alyssa by Lord Rogar Baratheon himself; an arrest warrant ensuring he reigned over Seven with unprecedented control.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The game of thrones takes many a queer turn, however, and Maegor himself had fallen in turn, in no small part thanks to the courage of the widowed Queen Alyssa, and the boldness of Lord Rogar, who had befriended her and taken her in when no one else would. The gods had been good to them and granted them victory, and now the woman who had been Alyssa of House Velaryon was to be given a second chance at happiness with a new husband.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Maegor had fallen in with a rough crowd, and Queen Alyssa of House Velaryon had taken him in and granted him a queer kind of courage, which she admired. Maegor was strong not only in boldness but also in his second chances. He befriended Lord Rogar Baratheon and the two were often seen riding all around him or sparring together at House Velaryon’s gates. Despite past feuds and broken relationships, Maegor seemed happier than he had been when he was five-and-thirty years of age. Now almost every night, Rogar could be found seated with Maegor at The Drunken Knight tavern alongside Qarl Corbray from Riverrun and Aerea Targaryen of Dragonstone; drinking ale, singing songs, and battle tales until the early dawn hours.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The wedding of the King’s Hand and the Queen Regent was to be as splendid as that of the widowed Queen Rhaena had been modest. The High Septon himself would perform the marriage rites, on the seventh day of the seventh moon of the new year. The site would be the half- completed Dragonpit, still open to the sky, whose rising tiers of stone benches would allow for tens of thousands to observe the nuptials. The celebrations would include a great tourney, seven days of feasts and frolics, and even a mock sea battle to be fought in the waters of Blackwater Bay.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Another of the King’s Hand's great achievements was arranging a grand wedding between Queen Rhaena Targaryen and the High Septon, as well as in-depth negotiations with the Archon of Tyrosh for Princess Aerea's marriage to Lord Darry. The festivities at Dragonpit included marriage rites, a great tourney amongst knights from all around Westeros, feasts and frolics along Blackwater Bay and finally a spectacular mock sea battle that had everyone cheering. These lavish performances required architecture, decoration and planning that made even the greatest cities look modestly plain. Since it was overseen by the King’s Hand himself and performed in aid of good religion with splendid ceremony, there could be no doubt of its success or beauty; one could only hope its effect on both populace would last beyond this very gathering.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: No wedding half so magnificent had been celebrated in Westeros in living memory, and lords great and small from throughout the Seven Kingdoms and beyond gathered to be part of it. Donnel Hightower came up from Oldtown with a hundred knights and seventy-seven of the Most Devout, escorting His High Holiness the High Septon, whilst Lyman Lannister brought three hundred knights from Casterly Rock. Brandon Stark, the ailing Lord of Winterfell, made the long journey down from the North with his sons Walton and Alaric, attended by a dozen fierce northern bannermen and thirty Sworn Brothers of the Night’s Watch. Lords Arryn, Corbray, and Royce represented the Vale, Lords Selmy, Dondarrion, and Tarly the Dornish Marches. Even from beyond the borders of the realm the great and mighty came; the Prince of Dorne sent his sister, the Sealord of Braavos a son. The Archon of Tyrosh crossed the narrow sea himself with his maiden daughter, as did no fewer than twenty-two magisters from the Free City of Pentos. All brought handsome gifts to bestow on the Hand and Queen Regent; the most lavish came from those who had only lately been Maegor’s men, and from Rickard Rowan and Torgen Oakheart, who had marched with Septon Moon.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The wedding of Donnel Hightower and Rhaena Targaryen was celebrated with a magnificent gathering in Westeros. Notables such as his High Holiness, Lyman Lannister and Brandon Stark had escorting them their fierce northern bannermen, while from small to great gathered Lords Arryn and Corbray, Royce and Selmy, Dondarrion and Tarly - even the Prince of Dorne, Sealord of Braavos and Archon of Tyrosh along with aling Maegor's men. The feast began at Dragonpit where Rickard Rowan lit the torches of welcome alongside Torgen Oakheart to receive His High Holiness; followed by entertainers perfoming for the mighty-lord. Even Septon Moon gathered some ancient artifacts from all over Westeros which adorned the walls around them adding a sense of splendor!

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The wedding guests came ostensibly to celebrate the union of Rogar Baratheon and the Dowager Queen, but they had other reasons for attendance, it should not be doubted. Many wished to treat with the Hand, who was seen by many as the true power in the realm; others wished to take the measure of their new boy king. Nor did His Grace deny them that opportunity. Ser Gyles Morrigen, the king’s champion and sworn shield, announced that Jaehaerys would be pleased to grant audience to any lord or landed knight who wished to meet with him, and sixscore accepted his invitation. Eschewing the great hall and the majesty of the Iron Throne, the young king entertained the lords in the intimacy of his solar, attended only by Ser Gyles, a maester, and a few servants.
events: wedding guests came ostensibly to celebrate the union
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The wedding guests came ostensibly to celebrate the union between Rogar Baratheon and Dowager Queen Jaehaerys, but underlying their festivities was a desire to take the measure of the true power in the realm - with a young king on the Iron Throne, many wanted to grant audience to those closest to him. Ser Gyles Morrigen, Hand of King Jaehaerys and maester of House Targaryen accompanied by servants led them into the grand hall after a lavish treat in his solar. All around him were magnificently decorated lords, fierce northern bannermen who had gathered for this momentous occasion and small retainers from as far as Oldtown and Casterly Rock escorting their respective ailing lieges. His High Holiness celebrated by granting blessings even amidst numerous enemies present in Westeros. When all was ready, King Jaeaeryys welcomed each guest with great respect, eager to unite them albeit briefly under one roof after so much discord.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: There, it is said, he encouraged each man to speak freely and share his views on the problems of the realm and how they might best be overcome. “He is not his father’s son,” Lord Royce told his maester afterward; grudging praise mayhaps, but praise all the same. Lord Vance of Wayfarer’s Rest was heard to say, “He listens well, but says little.” Rickard Rowan found Jaehaerys gentle and soft-spoken, Kyle Connington thought him witty and good-humored, Morton Caron cautious and shrewd. “He laughs often and freely, even at himself,” Jon Mertyns said approvingly, but Alec Hunter thought him stern, and Torgen Oakheart grim. Lord Mallister pronounced him wise beyond his years, whilst Lord Darry said he promised to be “the sort of king any lord should be proud to kneel to.” The most profound praise came from Brandon Stark, Lord of Winterfell, who said, “I see his grandsire in him.”
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys I Targaryen sat on the Iron Throne in the great hall of King's Landing, beckoning to be addressed. He encouraged every Lord in the realm to speak freely and share their counsel as his father once did. It soon became apparent that this was a wise young king who was both soft-spoken and witty, yet shrewd. As he listened intently, laughed at jokes and treated each Lord with equanimity, they took the measure of true power in the realm felt comforted by Jaehaerys' good-humored nature, only growing more cautious when he spoke sternly or grew grim despite his tender fifteen years of age. From Lord Royce to Lord Vance of Wayfarer’s Rest, Rickard Rowan to Kyle Connington, Morton Caron to Jon Mertyns; all found themselves moved whenever Jaehaerys smiled upon them and promised swift justice for loyal service. With Brandon Stark amongst those gathered lords from around The Seven Kingdoms; it seemed even bloodshed between family had not cooled Jaime's hot spirit so recently stoked by his father's Golden Wedding and Targaryens' ascent from Maegor Cruel’s grievous tyranny onto Jaehaerys’s throne.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The King’s Hand attended none of these audiences, but it should not be thought that Lord Rogar was an inattentive host. The hours his lordship spent with his guests were devoted to other pursuits, however. He hunted with them, hawked with them, gambled with them, feasted with them, and “drank the royal cellars dry.” After the wedding, when the tourney began, Lord Rogar was present for every tilt and every melee, surrounded by a lively and oft drunken coterie of great lords and famous knights.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: At Lord Rogar's wedding and tournament, The King's Hand attended and indulged in the activity that was most common in the realm. He hunted, hawked, gambled, feasted, drank and was present but often inattentive; lively yet oft drunken. All around him were familiar faces - Jaehaerys and his Lords Royce, Vance of Wayfarer’s Rest, Rowan, Connington, Caron, Mertyns, Hunterand Oakheart alongside Darryand Brandon Stark. They encouraged each other to speak freely and share stories as Rickard laughed frequently while Kyle was soft-spoken yet witty. Lord Mallisterwas both good-humored yet cautious while Lord Darrywas shrewd having promised many wise words over the years though also stern moments of grim warnings.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The most notorious of his lordship’s entertainments occurred two days before the ceremony, however. Though no record of it exists in any court chronicle, tales told by servants and repeated for many years thereafter amongst the smallfolk claim that Lord Rogar’s brothers had brought seven virgins across the narrow sea from the finest pleasure houses of Lys. Queen Alyssa had surrendered her own maidenhood many years before to Aenys Targaryen, so there could be no question of Lord Rogar deflowering her on their wedding night. The Lysene maidens were meant to make up for that lack. If the whispers heard about court afterward were true, his lordship supposedly plucked the flowers of four of the girls before exhaustion and drink did him in; his brothers, nephews, and friends did for the other three, along with twoscore older beauties who had sailed with them from Lys.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003:
On the wedding night, Lord Rogar, Queen Alyssa and Prince Aenys Targaryen gathered in a secluded room off the great hall at Lys. Tales of what occurred that night are whispered all around - some say it was love at first sight between Lord Rogar and Aenys' young bride; others speak that darkness existed beneath the surface and something sinister lurked in every corner. But whatever may have happened, it is known far and wide as one of most notorious events to have ever occurred on the narrow sea. 

That same day, Ser Walton Qarl Corbray brought his new wife, Lady Elissa Royce, to join them for a feast fit for the finest royal company - with feasting and drinking oft drunken by many smallfolk who had surrendered Lys to their notorious lords. On this wedding night much laughter rang through the halls as ale was plucked from table’s, numerous sails for she sailed away with her husband on his ship, Silverwing were made & games were played throughout until morning came.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Whilst the Hand roistered and King Jaehaerys sat in audience with the lords of the realm, his sister Princess Alysanne entertained the highborn women who had come with them to King’s Landing. The king’s elder sister, Rhaena, had chosen not to attend the nuptials, preferring to remain on Fair Isle with her own new husband and her court, and the Queen Regent Alyssa was busy with preparations for the wedding, so the task of playing hostess to the wives, daughters, and sisters of the great and mighty fell to Alysanne. Though she had only recently turned thirteen, the young princess rose to the challenge brilliantly, all agreed. For seven days and seven nights, she broke her fast with one group of highborn ladies, dined with a second, supped with a third. She showed them the wonders of the Red Keep, sailed with them on Blackwater Bay, and rode with them about the city.
verbs: broke her fast with one group of highborn ladies,
showed them the wonders of the Red Keep,
sailed with them on Blackwater Bay,
rode with them about the city.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The Hand and King Jaehaerys boisterously roistered around King's Landing in preparation for the wedding of Princess Alysanne and Rhaena Targaryen. Inspired by her magnanimousness, Queen Regent Alyssa saw to it that her chosen guests remain entertained throughout the event—breaking her fast with one group of ladies at Fair Isle, dining with a second at Red Keep and supping with a third along Blackwater Bay. She showed them the wonders of Red Keep, sailed with them around Blackwater Bay and rode about the city such that every highborn resident was able to be part of her Golden Wedding experience. Even amongst these lords and ladies came enemies, particularly those who remembered vividly when Maegor the Cruel burned his uncle Lord Rogar Baratheon alive in Lys or when he plucked out people’s eyes in a sat of violence not far away from where they currently were. Rumors continued to circulate as some pointedly mentioned how those same seven knights had only recently surrendered after sailing on Rhaela’s famous Sea Dragon Tower against Lord Rogar himself, still notorious amongst smallfolk even today. Nonetheless, Queen Alyssa rose to challenge brilliantly leaving each highborn attendee increasingly smitten by her gracious hospitality – thus becoming known as Her Grace's Finest Hour.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Alysanne Targaryen, the youngest child of King Aenys and Queen Alyssa, had been little known amongst the lords and ladies of the realm before then. Her childhood had been spent in the shadow of her brothers and her elder sister, Rhaena, and when she was spoken of at all it was as “the little maid” and “the other daughter.” She was little, this was true; slim and slight of frame, Alysanne was oft described as pretty but seldom as beautiful, though she was born of a house renowned for beauty. Her eyes were blue rather than purple, her hair a mass of honey-colored curls. No man ever questioned her wits.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Alysanne Targaryen had a slim and slight frame, but was well-known for her beauty. Her shining blue and purple eyes lit up any room she entered, while her honey-colored hair gave her an ethereal glow that captivated all who crossed her path. She was often heard to speak of the wonders she'd seen during the preparations for King Aenys's wedding to Queen Regent Alyssa; from the grandeur of King's Landing, to sailing along Blackwater Bay aboard Prince Rhaena's gaily painted cog Silverwing. Now with the challenge at hand, Princess Alysanne rose to it brilliantly - entertaining those in attendance and showing them all the wonders of Fair Isle by the Sunset Sea where his High Holiness Archon of Tyrosh declared Alysanne’s betrothal . With every stop on their journey across Westeros, Alysanne shone more brightly than ever before as if casting light on all those around her.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Later, it would be said of her that she learned to read before she was weaned, and the court fool would make japes about little Alysanne dribbling mother’s milk on Valyrian scrolls as she tried to read whilst suckling at her wet nurse’s teat. Had she been a boy she would surely have been sent to the Citadel to forge a maester’s chain, Septon Barth would say of her…for that wise man esteemed her even more than her husband, whom he served for so long. That was far in the future, however; in 49 AC, Alysanne was but a girl of thirteen years, yet all the chronicles agree that she made a powerful impression on those who met her.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Alysanne's wet nurse brought her to the Citadel, where Septon Barth read to her and weaned her off of dribbling on suckling. The powerful forge of knowledge that Alysanne was exposed to created a much different life than when she had been described as a slim, little girl with pretty blue eyes and honey-colored hair who was renowned for beauty by His Grace, King Aenys.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: When the day of the wedding finally arrived, more than forty thousand smallfolk ascended the Hill of Rhaenys to the Dragonpit to bear witness to the union of the Queen Regent and the Hand. (Some observers put the count even higher.) Thousands more cheered Lord Rogar and Queen Alyssa in the streets as their procession made its way across the city, attended by hundreds of knights on caparisoned palfreys, and columns of septas ringing bells. “Never has there been such a glory in all the annals of Westeros,” wrote Grand Maester Benifer. Lord Rogar was clad head to heel in cloth-of-gold beneath an antlered halfhelm, whilst his bride wore a greatcloak sparkling with gemstones, with the three-headed dragon of House Targaryen and the silver seahorse of the Velaryons facing one another on a divided field.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The wedding of Queen Regent Alyssa and Lord Rogar Baratheon was the day Westeros had waited for. The Hill of Rhaenys was a-bustle with caparisoned horses, participants adorned in sparkling jewels, smallfolk cheering bystanders, divided by royal procession banners and greatcloaks draped over antlered Sigils. Grand Maester Benifer's voice ascended as he pronounced them man and wife while cheers erupted from all around the Dragonpit. As they rode towards Westeros in their carriages drawn by steeds, silver streaming behind them like a tale never ending, the faithful cheered. People shouted 'Long live the queen!' and waved flags embroidered with an anltered sigil until their carriage disappeared into the horizon leaving only a faint glimmer on tales of love ascension amidst enemies.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Yet for all the splendor of the bride and groom, it was the arrival of Alyssa’s children that set King’s Landing to talking for years to come. King Jaehaerys and Princess Alysanne were the last to appear, descending from a bright sky on their dragons, Vermithor and Silverwing (the Dragonpit still lacked the great dome that would be its crowning glory, it must be recalled), their great leathern wings stirring up clouds of sand as they came down side by side, to the awe and terror of the gathered multitudes. (The oft-told tale that the arrival of the dragons caused the aged High Septon to soil his robes is likely only a calumny.)
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa and the smallfolk cheered as she ascended the Hill of Rhaenys in her sparkling caparisoned horse to witness her children's arrival. Vermithor and Silverwing, Jaehaerys and Alysanne, descended from the sky before the Dragonpit stirring a cloud of dust that lay heavy over King’s Landing despite its splendor and bright summer day. All around him great leathern wings stirred the air but none were as startling or great as when Queen Alyssa's children brought with them a foreboding of something larger to come. Lord Rogar Baratheon was there amongst many Targaryen loyalists who had been invited by the new queen regent to celebrate this joyous occasion and Walton from House Royce stood among those who watched with admiration at this great Golden Wedding; all of which set face for battles yet to come for Westeros against Maegor's men and various enemies throughout the realm.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Of the ceremony itself, and the feast and bedding that followed in due course, we need say little. The Red Keep’s cavernous throne room hosted the greatest of the lords and the most distinguished of the visitors from across the sea; lesser lords, together with their knights and men-at-arms, celebrated in the yards and smaller halls of the castle, whilst the smallfolk of King’s Landing made merry in a hundred inns, wine sinks, pot shops, and brothels. Notwithstanding his purported exertions two nights prior, it is reliably reported that Lord Rogar performed his husbandly duties with vigor, cheered on by his drunken brothers.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar, the strong and distinguished Lord of Storm's End, hosted a grand feast at the Red Keep in King's Landing to celebrate Alyssa’s children’s arrival and to perform the bedding ceremony. As heralded by every Targaryen for generations, it was one of the greatest feasts ever seen as visitors from many far corners of Westeros and even beyond made merry on silk carpets. Vessels of wine decorated with jewels were brought out from cups made of gold while lesser lords from surrounding lands got drunker by the minute. Whatever stirrings had been left behind upon their descending into soil below Dragonpit turned into forgotten splendor amidst the bright light that found its way through every corner of King's Landing that night.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Seven days of tourney followed the wedding, and kept the gathered lords and the people of the city enthralled. The tilts were as hard- fought and thrilling as had been seen in Westeros in many a year, all agreed…but it was the battles fought afoot with sword and spear and axe that truly excited the passions of the crowd on this occasion, and for good reason.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar had hosted and celebrated the ceremony, feast and bedding of the marriage between his nephew, Lord Darry Baratheon to Aerea Royce at Red Keep in King's Landing. After the joyous event, excitement quickly spread throughout Westeros as people heard news of an announcement by His Grace that a tourney was to be held in honor of the great union. Those privileged enough kept their eyes peeled for more information while others made merry over the fact that they could look forward to a thrilling hard-fought tournament. Around this same time, passions ran high with word that another wedding would soon follow for Princess Rhaenys Targaryen of House Oswyck to Drunken Knight Alec Hunter, son of Prince Aenys Hunter.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: It will be recalled that three of the seven knights who served as Maegor the Cruel’s Kingsguard were dead; the remaining four had been sent to the Wall to take the black. In their places, King Jaehaerys had thus far named only Ser Gyles Morrigen and Ser Joffrey Doggett. It was the Queen Regent, Alyssa, who first put forward the idea that the remaining five vacancies be filled through test of arms, and what better occasion for it than the wedding, when knights from all over the realm would gather? “Maegor had old men, lickspittles, cravens, and brutes about him,” she declared. “I want the knights protecting my son to be the finest to be found anywhere in Westeros, true honest men whose loyalty and courage is unquestioned. Let them win their cloaks with deeds of arms, whilst all the realm looks on.”
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Maegor the Cruel, King Jaehaerys, and Alyssa all gathered atop The Wall for a test of arms. It was a thrilling event that brought people from Westeros and beyond to the northern most limits of the realm. As seven knights stepped forward, Valytian named them five old for their loyalty and courageous unquestioned bearing. Among those selected were Walton Qarl Corbray, Lord Darry, Samantha Stokeworth's Hand, His Grace Osceyck Drunken Knight, Alec Hunter and Prince Aenys Targaryen. Maeger declared that he hand-picked each knight himself with no counsel from his advisors and enemies alike sat in awe of his esteemed selection.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: King Jaehaerys was quick to second his mother’s notion, but with a practical twist of his own. Sagely, the young king decreed that his would-be protectors should prove their prowess afoot, not in the joust. “Men who would do harm to their king seldom attack on horseback with lance in hand,” His Grace declared. And so it was that the tilts that followed his mother’s wedding yielded pride of place to the wild melees and bloody duels the maesters would dub the War for the White Cloaks.
events: tilts that followed his mother's wedding
the War for the White Cloaks
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: King Jaehaerys, declared the second Hand of the King of Westeros, had decreed an attack on enemies who had yielded quick and wise decisions with his own prowess afoot at the tilts that followed Maegor's wedding. After winning the War for the White Cloaks to great fanfare and acclaim, Lady Elissa Royce put forward her five remaining sons as loyal and courageous candidates for His Grace. Joining those two old hands were five designated seven by Queen Alyssa: Prince Aenys Targaryen, Lord Darry, Walton Corbray, Qarl Corbray, and Ser Alyn Silverwing. All unquestioned in their courage in battle, summoned from near and far King's Landing to gather around him; it was this group that truly marked of beginnings of Maegor's reign as maester Lucinda declared it "the Golden Wedding".

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: With hundreds of knights eager to compete for the honor of serving in the Kingsguard, the combats lasted seven full days. Several of the more colorful competitors became favorites of the smallfolk, who cheered them raucously each time they fought. One such was the Drunken Knight, Ser Willam Stafford, a short, stout, big-bellied man who always appeared so intoxicated that it was a wonder he could stand, let alone fight. The commons named him “the Keg o’ Ale,” and sang “Hail, Hail, Keg o’ Ale” whenever he took the field. Another favorite of the commons was the Bard of Flea Bottom, Tom the Strummer, who mocked his foes with ribald songs before each bout. The slender mystery knight known only as the Serpent in Scarlet also had a great following; when finally defeated and unmasked, “he” proved to be a woman, Jonquil Darke, a bastard daughter of the Lord of Duskendale.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The Drunken Knight could be heard boasting of his prowess afoot as he and the Kingsguard journeyed through Flea Bottom. Far behind them, they left the combats they had been competing in, each hoping to be named the victor. The Bard of Flea Bottom mocked him good-naturedly while Tom the Strummer was eager to join in despite his intoxication. But all levity fell away when Ser Willam Stafford unmasked Jonquil Darke, also known as Serpent in Scarlet, famed for her colorful knife fights throughout Westeros and beyond. As every eye in the room widened with surprise it became clear that Daemon Targaryen had not only sent one of his storied knights halfway across Essos but also had a queen regent Alyssa at his side who's quick-thinking had yielded better results than any sagely counsel from King Jaehaerys' lords councillors could have hoped for.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: In the end, none of these would earn a white cloak. The knights who did, though less madcap, proved themselves second to none in valor, chivalry, and skill at arms. Only one was the scion of a lordly house; Ser Lorence Roxton, from the Reach. Two were sworn swords; Ser Victor the Valiant, from the household of Lord Royce of Runestone, and Ser Willam the Wasp, who served Lord Smallwood of Acorn Hall. The youngest champion, Pate the Woodcock, fought with a spear instead of a sword, and some questioned whether he was a knight at all, but he proved so skillful with his chosen weapon that Ser Joffrey Doggett settled the matter by dubbing the lad himself, whilst hundreds cheered.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Ser Lorence Roxton, Ser Victor the Valiant and Ser Willam the Wasp had earned their reputation as madcap knight of valor and were invited to the Reach for a Dubbing ceremony. At Runestone's Academy Hall, these five knights would prove their mettle in various competitions, fight each other and settled by swords. As the cheers echoed through walls of the ancient castle, few questioned this chivalry display until Pate the Woodcock emerged from amongst them with skillful swordsmanship that made him victorious above all others. It was at this moment that King Jaehaerys rewarded him with a knighthood dubbing him 'the lad', winning praises from Targaryens, lords councillors and enemies alike.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The eldest champion was a grizzled hedge knight named Samgood of Sour Hill, a scarred and battered man of three-and-sixty who claimed to have fought in a hundred battles “and never you mind on what side, that’s for me and the gods to know.” One-eyed, bald, and almost toothless, the knight called Sour Sam looked as gaunt as a fencepost, but in battle he displayed the quickness of a man half his age, and a vicious skill honed through long decades of battles great and small.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Samgood of Sour Hill was no young lad, but the eldest and grizzled knight, scarred and battered by a three-and-sixty campaign. He fought with one eye closed due to his blindness in the left eye while the other continuously searched for any unseen danger. His bald head held a few white strands which flew around as he moved with his toothless mouth wide open in concentration. Nonetheless he remained gaunt, fit from years campaigning around Westeros and quick to notice an enemy’s movement. As Samgood of Sour Hill displayed what honed skillful viciousness over many battles on the field of Reach alongside Ser Lorence Roxton, Ser Victor the valiant, Pate the Woodcock, Ser Joffrey Doggett and others; Ser Willam The Wasp settled any questions about Samgood's valor or chivalry that their madcap adventure may have provoked among them all.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Jaehaerys the Conciliator would sit the Iron Throne for fifty-five years, and many a knight would wear a white cloak in his service during that long reign, more than any other monarch could boast. But it was rightly said that never did any Targaryen possess a Kingsguard who could equal the boy king’s first Seven.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys could barely contain his excitement as he finally got to sit on the Iron Throne. He was determined to wear it like a crown and possess it like a Conciliator. The throne glimmering in white from one end of his sight, brought other tokens of first heritage; Samgood of Sour Hill whom fought and displayed grizzled, scarred, battered traits with three-and-sixty years - one-eyed, bald and toothless; the old gaunt frame quivered with a quickness never witnessed before - viciously honed through an age whose horrors knew no bounds.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The War for the White Cloaks marked the end of the festivities of what soon became known as the Golden Wedding. As the visitors took their leaves to wend their way home to their own lands and keeps, all agreed that it had been a magnificent event. The young king had won the admiration and affection of many lords both great and small, and their sisters, wives, and daughters had only praise for the warmth shown them by Princess Alysanne. The smallfolk of King’s Landing were pleased as well; their boy king seemed to have every sign of being a just, merciful, and chivalrous ruler, and his Hand, Lord Rogar, was as open-handed as he was bold in battle. Happiest of all were the city’s innkeeps, taverners, brewers, merchants, cutpurses, whores, and brothel keepers, all of whom had profited mightily from the coin the visitors brought to the city.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The young King Jaehaerys had won the War for the White Cloaks and taken a seat on the Iron Throne. After being crowned, he wended his way to King's Landing for his Golden Wedding with Princess Alysanne, where Lord Rogar had shown up in magnificent fashion. He seemed to have profited from their alliance; as King Jaehaerys was known by many titles - The Conciliator, The Just, The Merciful and so on - yet Lord Rogar had recently been awarded with a lordship because of his loyalty to the Targaryens during the war. His open-handedness and boldness were equally celebrated amongst those who attended the Royal wedding. Although many of Maegor’s men still lingered in King’s Landing, they all bowed before him in respect as if he held some secret favor in court that no one else could possess.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Yet though the Golden Wedding was the most lavish and far-famed of the nuptials of 49 AC, the third of the marriages made in that fateful year would prove to be the most significant.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The grandeur of the Golden Wedding was sure to be unlike anything else Westeros had seen before. It seemed almost fateful that such a lavish celebration be held in King’s Landing to prove their glory and magnificence, as it had been ever since Aegon the Conqueror made his daring move on its gates. Prince Aenys Targaryen spared no expense for his nuptials - from bringing merchants from Tyrosh to provide exotic delicacies for the feast, to sending out invites to all corners of Westeros so that even enemies could witness the union between Lord Rogar Baratheon and Princess Alysanne. The seven knights of Jaehaerys’s Kingsguard stood watch over the ceremony, while Queen Regent Alyssa herself presided over proceedings. An extravagance like this had never been seen before in any court at any time in history - which made it all the more fitting when young King Aenys Targaryen said “I do!”  with great joy and fervour.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: With their own wedding now safely behind them, the Queen Regent and the King’s Hand next turned their attention to finding a suitable match for King Jaehaerys…and, to a lesser extent, for his sister Princess Alysanne. So long as the boy king remained unwed and without issue, the daughters of his sister Rhaena would remain his heirs…but Aerea and Rhaella were still children, and, it was felt by many, manifestly unfit for the crown.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Queen Regent Alyssa had the privilege and honor of presiding over King Jaehaerys's wedding to Princess Alysanne, along with her siblings, Aerea and Rhaena, who remained un-wed and without issue. The royal nuptials were a lavish affair that proved far-famed, likened as the fateful Golden Wedding between Queen Rhaenys and Lord Oswyck. The festivities spanned several days in Westeros with King’s Hand present all throughout, for it was suitable for the queenly entourage to feel content in presence of all seven knights of Jaehaerys’s Kingsguard who manifested their fitness to serve the manifestly unfit boy king. As gentlemen Sir Walton Corbray, Lord Darry, Qarl Corbray alongside His Grace Samantha Stokeworth attended their lordly betters in audience while Lady Elissa Caron hosted Ladies Alayne Royce and Lucinda Connington amongst others atop at Sea Dragon Tower. With her Lady Rogar Baratheon presiding as esteemed matron-of-honor hosted folk including Kyle Connington across Claws Isle till near morning amidst Her Grace’s prudent stewardship with Rickard Rowan commanding rows upon rows of courtiers from Winterfell north aligned into reverence around Iron Throne less than broke away if mustered needed thereby underpinning Queen Regent’s influence felt all around - irrespective of ale or silverwinged Serpent in Scarlet!

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Moreover, Lord Rogar and Queen Alyssa both feared what might befall the realm should Rhaena Targaryen return from the west to act as regent for a daughter. Though none dared speak of it, it was plain that discord had arisen between the two queens, for the daughter had neither attended her mother’s wedding nor invited her to her own. And there were some who went further and whispered that Rhaena was a sorceress, who had used the dark arts to murder Maegor upon the Iron Throne. Therefore it was incumbent upon King Jaehaerys to marry and beget a son as soon as possible.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar of the west, who had once been feared and whispered by many to be the one who murdered Queen Alyssa Targaryen, had come to King Jaehaerys's court for a betrothal. Rhaena Targaryen, the young bride was plain yet his uncle saw it fit for him to wed her and beget children when other Lords were manifestly unfit for it since remaining unwed without issue could bring discordant thoughts in a royal family like theirs. On their wedding day not just Lord Rogar's kin but kings from all corners of Westeros as well as enemies outside Oldtown gathered at Silverwing's castle to witness this union thus known as The Golden Wedding. But what seemed dark was that only king Jaehaerys himself and seven knights of his Kingsguard escort them along with Lord Rogar while no members from Queen Regent Alyssa or King’s Hand Accolon’s families were present around them which made everyone fear even more if Maegor's men might have been behind this conspiracy.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The question of who the young king might marry was less easily resolved. Lord Rogar, who was known to harbor thoughts of extending the power of the Iron Throne across the narrow sea to Essos, put forward the notion of forging an alliance with Tyrosh by wedding Jaehaerys to the Archon’s daughter, a comely girl of fifteen years who had charmed all at the wedding with her wit, her flirtatious manner, and her blue-green hair.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar, the soon-to-be husband of Archon's daughter in Tyrosh, had thought himself resolved to his fate until he arrived at the Iron Throne. The colorful and exotic murmurings of distant Essos were harboring an even darker truth: whispers of King Jaehaerys's murdered brother being begot on a plain Essoese maiden had been around for years in Westeros, creating discordant unease for those who knew about it. Despite this looming darkness that seemed to follow him everywhere, Lord Rogar was still taken aback by the charm and comely face of his young bride - her wit and flirtatious demeanor immediately brightening his gloomy state when their eyes met for the first time amidst his old cold seat atop Sea Dragon Tower. His blue-green eyes filled with wonder as he looked upon the Land's most feared family - House Targaryen put forward a new generation of true rulers finding balance through forging powerful political alliances between them and more pressing enemies within Westeros.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: In this, however, his lordship found himself opposed by his own wife, Queen Alyssa. The smallfolk of Westeros would never accept a foreign girl with dyed tresses as their queen, she argued, no matter how delightful her accent. And the pious would oppose the girl bitterly, for it was known that the Tyroshi kept not the Seven, but worshipped Red R’hllor, the Patternmaker, three-headed Trios, and other queer gods. Her own preference was to look to the houses who had risen in support of Aegon the Uncrowned in the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye. Let Jaehaerys wed a Vance, a Corbray, a Westerling, or a Piper, she urged. Loyalty should be rewarded, and by making such a match the king would honor Aegon’s memory, and the valor of those who fought and died for him.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa and Aegon the Uncrowned had been worshipped as monarchs of Westeros during the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye, but they had always opposed one another. Lord Rogar Baratheon had urged them both to accept each other's foreign believes if not for loyalty alone. Nevertheless, Queen Alyssa found it difficult to follow due to her pious belief in the Seven. She even earned her rightful nickname 'queen of charms' for her delightful, flirtatious nature that beguiled all those around her—from old folks like His Grace Dowager Queen Elinor Caron to young men such as Ser Kyle Connington and his uncle Lord Alec Hunter alike. Seeing this queer quality in the queen urged Aegon the Uncrowned on further still in what seemed like a one-sided battle of wits between the two royal figures.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: It was Grand Maester Benifer who spoke loudest against such a course, pointing out that the sincerity of their commitment to peace and reconciliation might be doubted if they were seen to favor those who had fought for Aegon over those who had remained with Maegor. A better choice, he felt, would be a daughter of one of the great houses that had taken little or no part in the battles between uncle and nephew; a Tyrell, a Hightower, an Arryn.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Grand Maester Benifer spoke in favor of Aegon, urging for their commitment to peace and reconciliation. His words were felt the loudest, making a great impression among those present. Queen Alyssa looked briefly at her son Maegor, recognizing his deeply pious and loyal devotion to his foreign gods which she found both delightful and queer yet accepted with grace. He had been worshipping seven deities since they had arrived at Westeros after the Battle Beneath The Gods Eye and was determined to oppose any challengers presented to him by his enemies along the way.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: With the King’s Hand, the Queen Regent, and the Grand Maester so divided, other councillors felt emboldened to put forward candidates of their own. Prentys Tully, the royal justiciar, nominated a younger sister of his own wife, Lucinda, famed for her piety. Such a choice would surely please the Faith. Daemon Velaryon, the lord admiral, suggested that Jaehaerys might marry the widowed Queen Elinor, of House Costayne. How better to show that Maegor’s supporters had been forgiven than by taking one of his Black Brides to queen, mayhaps even adopting her three sons by her first marriage. Queen Elinor’s proven fertility was another point in her favor, he argued. Lord Celtigar had two unwed daughters, and had famously offered Maegor his choice of them; now he offered the same girls again for Jaehaerys. Lord Baratheon was having none of it. “I have seen your daughters,” Rogar said to Celtigar. “They have no chins, no teats, and no sense.”
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The Queen Regent and King's Hand had gathered many lords of Westeros who seen to suggest marriage between the vast, yet unspoken royalty. Grand Maester Benifer proposed Prentys Tully to Lucinda, Daemon Velaryon to Elinor, Costayne to Maegor and Rogar Baratheon for Jaehaerys. With each suggestion came a word of their piety, fertility and even words of wisdom on behalf of those in favor or against this union. Their loudest speeches proved great in persuading the young king away from any commitment to peace and reconciliation as he saw fit with nomination suggested by his uncle.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The Queen Regent and her councillors discussed the question of the king’s marriage time and time again over most of a moon’s turn, but came no closer to reaching a consensus. Jaehaerys himself was not privy to these debates. On this Queen Alyssa and Lord Rogar agreed. Though Jaehaerys might well be wise beyond his years, he was still a boy, and ruled by a boy’s desires, desires that on no account could be allowed to overrule the good of the realm. Queen Alyssa in particular had no doubt whatsoever about whom her son would choose to marry were the choice left to him: her youngest daughter, his sister the Princess Alysanne.
events: discussed the question of the king's marriage
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The Queen Regent, along with her councillors, had discussed the question of the king's marriage and debated how to reach a decision. Lord Rogar Baratheon was privy to these heated debates and time and time again his wise counsel allowed him to overrule even the most senior among them. The young royal agreed that Queen Alyssa would be an ideal candidate for wedlock, given her piety and fertility – she was still unwed at 25 years old. In addition he suggested Princess Alysanne Targaryen, who was also present in the court hall today. The council members were taken aback by this suggestion but eventually reached consensus when they realised that the King could override their opinions if desired; after-all he was wise beyond his years.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The Targaryens had been marrying brother to sister for centuries, of course, and Jaehaerys and Alysanne had grown up expecting to wed, just as their elder siblings Aegon and Rhaena had. Morever, Alysanne was only two years younger than her brother, and the two children had always been close and strong in their affection and regard for one another. Their father, King Aenys, would certainly have wished for them to marry, and once that would have been their mother’s wish as well…but the horrors she had witnessed since her husband’s death had persuaded Queen Alyssa to think elsewise. Though the Warrior’s Sons and Poor Fellows had been disbanded and outlawed, many former members of both orders remained at large in the realm and might well take up their swords again if provoked. The Queen Regent feared their wroth, for she had vivid memories of all that had befallen her son Aegon and her daughter Rhaena when their marriage was announced. “We dare not ride that road again,” she is reported to have said, more than once.
adjectives: brother-sister centuries, expected, elder siblings, two years younger, close and strong, vivid memories
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: As the various Targaryens grew older, marriage became more of a pressing matter. Queen Alyssa had been persuaded to allow her brother-sister centuries old subject to be disbanded and outlawed in Westeros. But it was expected that Jaehaerys, being two years younger than his elder siblings, would wed once he was old enough: they held close and strong vivid memories from when the councilors discussed how the King's marriage would reach an accord between rival Houses - something that wise beyond his years Jaehaerys had been privy to time and time again; even allowing himself to overrule some opinions given by the Queen Regent on certain occasions. Yet none could have foreseen what was about to happen as Princess Alysanne forcibly persuaded her husband King Aenys that no one should be made to marry if they did not wish it so. This unexpected turn of events disrupted alllord plans when marrying off Aegon, Rhaena or any of their other children just for peace between those same royal allies who had taken up swords against them yet again - provoking outrage with their actions but at least proving themselves loyal brothers and sisters if nothing else.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: In this resolve she was supported by the newest member of the court, Septon Mattheus of the Most Devout, who had remained in King’s Landing when the High Septon and the rest of his brethren returned to Oldtown. A great whale of a man, as famed for his corpulence as for the magnificence of his robes, Mattheus claimed descent from the Gardener kings of old, who had once ruled the Reach from their seat at Highgarden. Many regarded him as a near certainty to be chosen as the next High Septon.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Septon Mattheus accompanied the High Septon and the King's Landing delegation to Oldtown, in the Reach. The newly appointed and most esteemed High Septon was regarded highly even by the famed Kings of old - Gardener kings who had reigned in splendour and magnificence until they were driven away by Aegon. And while many of their customs had remained long after they were gone, such as marrying siblings to one another, not even Aegon himself could persuade this High Septon to accept it and he had disbanded his court of educated men, outlawing it entirely. However, some whispered that despite his disposition towards this practice that he too held vivid memories growing up close with his elder siblings - two years younger than him - till a certain brother-sister marriage provoked them both enough to take up swords again, something which had been expected from centuries past.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The present occupant of that holy office, whom Septon Moon had derided as the High Lickspittle, was cautious and complaisant, so there was little to no danger of any marriage being denounced from Oldtown so long as he continued to speak for the Seven from his seat in the Starry Sept. The Father of the Faithful was not a young man, however; the journey to King’s Landing to officiate at the Golden Wedding had almost been the end of him, men said.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Septon Moon was a young and inexperienced man, known amongst the smallfolk of Oldtown as the High Lickspittle. The news of his appointment to officiate at the Golden Wedding between High Septon and Father of Faithful had astonished many in King's Landing, who derided him for his lack of knowledge and experience. But on the day of the ceremony he spoke with an unsettling holy authority that silenced those who doubted him. His cautious yet complaisant speech earned him admiration among clergy and faithful alike, while members of both families were pleasantly surprised by how little they their new septon had fumbled. Little did anyone know that this seemingly inconsequential young man would eventually become one of the most famed figures in Seven Kingdoms, regarded even by maegor himself with magnificence.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: “If it should fall to me to don his mantle, His Grace of course would have my support in any choice he might make,” Septon Mattheus assured the Queen Regent and her advisors, “but not all of my brethren are so inclined, and…dare I say…there are other Moons out there. Given all that has occurred, to marry brother to sister at this juncture would be seen as a grievous affront to the pious, and I fear for what might happen.”
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Septon Mattheus arrived in Oldtown on the Queen Regent's orders. He was accompanied by two of her advisors and also a few other trusted servants, for fear that something grievous might ocurred if he were to fall into the wrong hands. The Septon had been chosen to officiate the much derided Golden Wedding between Lord Rogar Baratheon and his young bride Lucinda, and he could see why there were so many who wanted nothing more than to have him say no when they are so inclined. Nevertheless, the holy man took a cautious yet little complaisant attitude towards it all as he considered it his duty to know little or nothing that may transpire within King's Landing, and with only days spent there since his arrival already enough knowledge seemed to find its way out through whispers.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Their queen’s misgivings thus confirmed, Rogar Baratheon and the other lords put aside all consideration of Princess Alysanne as a bride for her brother Jaehaerys. The princess was three-and-ten years of age, and had recently celebrated her first flowering, so it was thought desirable to see her wed as soon as possible. Though still far apart as regarded a suitable match for the king, the council settled swiftly on a partner for the princess; she would be married on the seventh day of the new year, to Orryn Baratheon, the youngest of Lord Rogar’s brothers.
events: married on the seventh day of the new year
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Rogar Baratheon had to put aside his misgivings when Queen Regent Alyssa thought it desirable for him to marry Princess Alysanne in order to settle the conflict between House Targaryen and House Baratheon. Celebrations for young bride's first flowering were quickly arranged, and on the seventh day of the new year, Rogar married Alysanne at Fair Isle by the Sunset Sea. Despite some apprehension from his uncle, Lord Orryn Baratheon and their enemies from House Tyrell, their union was celebrated like a Golden Wedding with lavish parties all around them. With Jaehaerys as King, Seven Knights of his Kingsguard stood guard and everyone in Westeros rejoiced as they feared no more grievous ocurrances after such a suitable joining of two great houses.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Thus it was settled by the Queen Regent and the King’s Hand and their lords councillors and advisors. But like many such arrangements through the ages, their plan was soon undone, for they had grievously underestimated the will and determination of Alysanne Targaryen herself, and her young king, Jaehaerys.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Queen Regent Alyssa, the widow of King Jaehaerys Targaryen and mother to the boy king Aenys, was undeterred by her husband's misgivings on what thought desirable. Swiftly setting aside her own desires, she swiftly agreed to the arrangements set out by Rogar Baratheon at their Golden Wedding procession, including marrying Princess Alysanne Targaryen to his eldest son Orryn. But no one had underestimated Queen Regent Alysa's will and determination; before the plans could be fully executed they were quickly undone by herself as she dispatched Lord Vance of Wayfarer's Rest and Seven Knights of Jaehaerys's Kingsguard on a quest for vengeance against enemieswho had wronged them both in Lys.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: No announcement had yet been made of Alysanne’s betrothal, so it is not known how word of the decision reached her ears. Grand Maester Benifer suspected a servant, for many such had come and gone whilst the lords debated in the queen’s solar. Lord Rogar himself was suspicious of Daemon Velaryon, the lord admiral, a prideful man who might well have believed that the Baratheons were overreaching themselves in hopes of displacing the Lords of the Tide as the second house in the realm. Years later, when these events had passed into legend, the smallfolk would tell each other that “rats in the walls” had overheard the lords talking and rushed to the princess with the news.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Alysanne and Grand Maester Benifer had reached the queen's solar, with Lord Rogar and Daemon Velaryon in tow. They were met by a stern yet prideful servant of the Queen Regent who had underestimated her will and determination. Much to their dismay, they found out that plans long settled and arrangements made had been undone much like before -- all because of her overreaching decision that passed earlier today. Undeterred, they consulted endlessly until an agreement was forged between them all in order to undo the mistakes of its predecessor.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: No record survives of what Alysanne Targaryen said or thought when first she learned that she was to be wed to a youth ten years her senior, whom she scarcely knew and (if rumor can be believed) did not like. We know only what she did. Another girl might have wept or raged or run pleading to her mother.
