In many a sad song, maidens forced to wed against their will throw themselves from tall towers to their deaths. Princess Alysanne did none of these things. Instead she went directly to Jaehaerys.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Alysanne Targaryen wept silently and raged against the fates that had thrown her into an arranged marriage with her cousin Jaehaerys. She ran up to the highest tower of Storm’s End, a castle along the Dornish Marches, pleading for something - anything - to be changed. Her tall frame could not shake this sad reality as she watched Lord Rogar Baratheon, one of seven knights of Jaehaerys’s Kingsguard, arrive at the castle gates. It was his decision that ended her overreaching prideful plea, and Alysanne’s grief was felt all around him. Even Daemon Velaryon, Alysanne's servant from Tyrosh and son of Archon of Tyrosh, Pitsoo Prentys Tully reached out to console her. In spite of wild crying and throwing things around in desperation Grand Maester Benifer stayed a step ahead in time to help Alysanne Targaryen reach this unhappy decision before enemies like Alea Silverwing started planning deviousness against Westeros Commoners like herself.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The young king was as displeased as his sister at the news. “They will be making wedding plans for me as well, I do not doubt,” he deduced at once. Like his sister, Jaehaerys did not waste time with reproaches, recriminations, or appeals. Instead he acted. Summoning his Kingsguard, he instructed them to sail at once for Dragonstone, where he would meet them shortly. “You have sworn me your swords and your obedience,” he reminded his Seven. “Remember those vows, and speak no word of my departure.”
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The young king, Jaehaerys, was displeased at the arrangements for his wedding plans to be made on Dragonstone. His Kingsguard stood about him acting as a summing sworn to obey but the recriminations and reproaches continued until the Seven were forced to remember their place and remain silently in their sworn obedience. Soon enough though, Jaehaerys's voice softened and his appeals towards his Hand grew more pleading as he remembered of how deeply Alyssa had wept over her own arranged union when they lived at Lys some years ago. The boy king knew that whilst many across Westeros were repulsed by Maegor the Cruel's unions, it wasn't right for him to rage against his Queen Regent so soon after her tall figure had run to comfort him when elves of Sour Hill threw disparaging comments during Golden Wedding.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: That night, under cover of darkness, King Jaehaerys and Princess Alysanne mounted their dragons, Vermithor and Silverwing, and departed the Red Keep for the ancient Targaryen citadel below the Dragonmont. Reportedly the first words the young king spoke upon landing were, “I have need of a septon.”
events: departed the Red Keep for the ancient Targaryen citadel below the Dragonmount
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The King Jaehaerys and Princess Alysanne mounted their horses and departed the Red Keep for the ancient Targaryen citadel below the Dragonmont. As they rode through darkness, Jaehaerys spoke "Remember our oaths of obedience, speak no ill of those that have done us wrong", a statement made by his young bride which had displeased him shortly before. They were accompanied by newly sworn members of Jonathan Grell's Kingsguard as well as Lord Walon from House Frey, Archon Qarl Corbray from Tyrosh and Aerea Stone, a distant cousin to Lord Darry who now served loyally in The Hand's court at Kings Landing. Their journey was cloaked in secrecy but despite continuous appeals from Westerosi enemies sniffing their passage beneath the walls King'e Landing all gave way to Queen’s Regent’s orders as they ran them under Nine Banner Of Protection to ensure safety too her son and daughter on this fateful day.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The king, rightly, had no trust in Septon Mattheus, who would surely have betrayed their plans, but the sept on Dragonstone was tended by an old man named Oswyck, who had known Jaehaerys and Alysanne since their births, and instructed them in the mysteries of the Seven throughout their childhood. As a younger man, Septon Oswyck had ministered to King Aenys, and as a boy he had served as a novice in the court of Queen Rhaenys. He was more than familiar with the Targaryen tradition of sibling marriage, and when he heard the king’s command, he assented at once.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: King Jaehaerys had instructed his Hand, Lord Oswyck, to accompany him and Princess Alysanne on the journey to Dragonstone. When they arrived at the familiar Targaryen citadel below the Dragonmont, Septon Mattheus tended to them reverently as he knew his duty rightly. As Aenys and Rhaenys ran around the castle gates with joyous laughter echoing through darkness of night, King Jaehaerys spoke solemnly "We must never trust anyone so easily again, for our enemies can be anywhere." The old septon ministered words of wisdom in return, "Your Grace speaks rightly - You must remain vigilant." and he heard them assent before returning back his duties at Dragonstone.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The Kingsguard arrived from King’s Landing by galley a few days later. The following morning, as the sun rose, Jaehaerys Targaryen, the First of His Name, took to wife his sister Alysanne in the great yard at Dragonstone, before the eyes of gods and men and dragons. Septon Oswyck performed the marriage rites; though the old man’s voice was thin and tremulous, no part of the ceremony was neglected. The seven knights of the Kingsguard stood witness to the union, their white cloaks snapping in the wind. The castle’s garrison and servants looked on as well, together with a good part of the smallfolk of the fishing village that huddled below Dragonstone’s mighty curtain walls.
events: marriage between Jaehaerys and Alysanne in the great yard at Dragonstone
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys Targaryen arrived in King's Landing with his wife Alysanne and their retinue, led by Septon Oswyck. They went to Dragonstone shortly after, where Jaehaerys took to wife with a grand ceremony performed in the great yard. While he rightly heard his supplicants and ministered them with justice and compassion, Alysanne was often neglected as she stood there huddled alongside a few of her ladies-in-waiting watching the great white dragon swooping majestically over Dragonstone. Being the benevolent queen that she was, she looked on helplessly at the people she had vowed to protect even if it meant neglecting herself. It seemed her husband had no trust for her due to his old ways of tending to affairs of state. Little did he know that Oswyck had instructed Alysanne throughout everything every step of the way; still he assented although some said it wasn't rightly done.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: A modest feast followed the ceremony, and many toasts were drunk to the health of the boy king and his new queen. Afterward Jaehaerys and Alysanne retired to the bedchamber where Aegon the Conqueror had once slept beside his sister Rhaenys, but in view of the bride’s youth there was no bedding ceremony, and the marriage was not consummated.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys and Alysanne were finally alone in their new home. After being feasted, toasted and the bedding ceremony followed, both were drunk and so they retired for the night, consummating their modest wedding. There was no grandeur from before when his great-great grandfather Aegon The Conqueror took to wife Rhaenys with a hundred lords in attendance around them. But it seemed neither of them had noticed or cared, only looking forward to a bright future together as King and Queen in their own little world one floor away from the busy castle gates of King's Landing.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: That omission would prove to be of great importance when Lord Rogar and Queen Alyssa arrived belatedly from King’s Landing in a war galley, accompanied by a dozen knights, forty men-at-arms, Septon Mattheus, and Grand Maester Benifer, whose letters give us the most complete accounting of what transpired.
events: arrived belatedly in a war galley
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar, Queen Alyssa, Septon Mattheus and Grand Maester Benifer arrived belatedly in King's Landing in a war galley. What had transpired during their omission from the feast followed by toasts and bedding ceremony that were as drunk yet modest? Rumors of King Jaehaerys and his new queen Alysanne Targaryen who consummated their marriage reached all around Westeros but it proved true when Lord Darry, Hand of The Seven himself alongside Samantha Stokeworth showed up at the castle gates for Golden Wedding. All these events made clear that the Targaryens meant business though the same could not be said about King’s Landing where Prince Aenys's allies were making suspicious moves against his uncle, Aegon the Conqueror.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Jaehaerys and Alysanne met them inside the castle gates, holding hands. It is said that Queen Alyssa wept when she saw them. “You foolish children,” she said. “You know not what you’ve done.”
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The castle gates of King's Landing opened to reveal Jaehaerys and Queen Alyssa, with their entourage of Lord Rogar Baratheon, Septon Mattheus, Grand Maester Benifer, and the Targaryins retinue. All taken by surprise at the sudden arrival of the King on horseback and Queen in her palanquin. As tears fell from her eyes onto her cheeks, Queen Alyssa looked back at the galley that had just arrived belatedly - an omission she knew would prove costly yet had no alternative in those bitter moments before. Just as Alysanne shyly held onto one end of his cloak while they wept together - both aware how foolish it made them look but understanding each other's grief- a voice was heard from above said softly "Your Grace..." It was Walther Corbray standing atop a nearby tower as he looked down upon them fondly - mindful enough to prepare for a royal welcome despite what has transpired previously this day.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Then up spoke Septon Mattheus, his voice thunderous as he berated the king and queen and prophesized that this abomination would once more plunge all of Westeros into war. “They shall curse your incest from the Dornish Marches to the Wall, and every pious son of the Mother and the Father shall denounce you as the sinners you are.” The septon’s face grew red and swollen as he raved, Benifer tells us, and spittle sprayed from his lips.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The Septon Mattheus, who had been called by Queen Alyssa to stand witness before the castle gates as King Jaehaerys and Alysanne wept, stood at attention again when the new king and queen took their thrones. He berated them for their foolish actions and prophesized that the gods would cast a curse upon them for committing such an abomination. With tears in his pious eyes, red from weeping for hours on end, Mattheus denounced the folly of young love in a loud voice swollen with emotion. As he spoke, many of those standing within earshot felt fear descend upon them, realizing they were now living under a tainted rule according to this septon’s pronouncement. Through gritted teeth Lord Walton Qarl Corbray whispered reassuring words to Princess Aerea while Lady Elissa Darry - widow of Aegon's Vassal Hand - embraced Samantha Stokeworth until His Grace was done speaking.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Jaehaerys the Conciliator is rightly honored in the annals of the Seven Kingdoms for his calm demeanor and even temper, but let no man think that the fire of the Targaryens did not burn in his veins. He showed it then. When Septon Mattheus finally paused for a breath, the king said, “I will accept chastisement from Her Grace my mother, but not from you. Hold your tongue, fat man. If another word passes your lips, I will have them sewn shut.”
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys was honored to have the septon in his kingdom and had paused when Septon Mattheus began speaking. The king said, "Have no fear Septon. I burn with a calm even flame." He had listened intently as the fiery words of the prophetic curse unfolded before him. After he had heard it all, Jaehaerys solemnly declared that he would take Lord Darry from the Dornish Marches to join his advisors at King’s Landing, for surely His Grace should have someone wise enough to alleviate the abomination upon Westeros that was prophesized.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Septon Mattheus spoke no more. Lord Rogar was not so easily cowed. Blunt and to the point, he asked only if the marriage had been consummated. “Tell me true, Your Grace. Was there a bedding? Did you claim her maidenhead?” “No,” the king replied. “She is too young.”
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar, an ardent admirer of the king, was asked to take part in the bedding ceremony. Despite his cowed demeanor and blunt manner, he was honored to be a part of it. Septon Mattheus solemnly opened prayers for the bride whilst nobody moved or said a word as flames from invpeccable fireplaces sparked brightly yet everything stayed strangely calm even though fiery emotions seemed palpable that evening. After Lord Rogar spoke in amilder voice than usual, Jaehaerys nodded graciously and thanked him for coming this day - surely doing so not only pleased him but also those around him who looked on at them with respect and admiration.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: At that Lord Rogar smiled. “Good. You are not wed.” He turned to the knights who had accompanied him from King’s Landing. “Separate these children, gently if you please. Escort the princess to Sea Dragon Tower and keep her there. His Grace shall accompany us back to the Red Keep.” But as his men moved forward, the seven knights of Jaehaerys’s Kingsguard stepped up and drew their swords. “Come no closer,” warned Ser Gyles Morrigen. “Any man who lays a hand upon our king and queen shall die today.” Lord Rogar was dismayed. “Sheath your steel and move aside,” he commanded. “Have you forgotten? I am the King’s Hand.” “Aye,” old Sour Sam answered, “but we’re the Kingsguard, not the Hand’s guard, and it’s the lad who sits the chair, not you.” Rogar Baratheon bristled at Ser Samgood’s words, and answered, “You are seven. I have half a hundred swords behind me. A word from me and they will cut you to pieces.” “They might kill us,” replied young Pate the Woodcock, brandishing his spear, “but you will be the first to die, m’lord, you have my word upon that.”
events: separate these children, gently if you please
verbs: Sheath your steel and move aside
will be the first to die.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar smiled slyly as he accompanied the seven knights of Jaehaerys’s Kingsguard down the stairs of Red Keep, to the castle gates. He was escorted by Ser Gyles Morrigen and Sour Sam, along with Pate the Woodcock. As they arrived at the Sea Dragon Tower, Lord Rogar turned to His Grace, asking if he had forgotten his command: "have you forgotten? Separate these children gently if you please". At thiswords, all seven men drew their swords and shouted in unison: "come no closer! Sheath your steel and move aside". The Princess and her brother stood firm, proclaiming that if any were to come closer they would be cut to pieces. Lord Rogar stepped back and nodded proudly at them; "Kill us then", he said. "But know that I will be the first to die." Good - it pleased him that these two Targaryens would not be easily cowed. With a slight bow, Lord Rogar motioned for his escort to continue on their way as he gently ushered the children back into safety.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: What might have happened next no man can say, had not Queen Alyssa chosen that moment to speak. “I have seen enough death,” she said. “So have we all. Put up your swords, sers. What is done is done, and now we all must needs live with it. May the gods have mercy on the realm.” She turned to her children. “We shall go in peace. Let no man speak of what happened here today.” “As you command, Mother.” King Jaehaerys pulled his sister closer and put his arm around her. “But do not think that you shall unmake this marriage. We are one now, and neither gods nor men shall part us.” “Never,” his bride affirmed. “Send me to the ends of the earth and wed me to the King of Mossovy or the Lord of the Grey Waste, Silverwing will always bring me back to Jaehaerys.” And with that she raised herself onto her toes and lifted her face to the king, and he kissed her full upon the lips whilst all looked on.*
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa and King Jaehaerys had been married at the Red Keep, the marriage attended by many powerful figures from across the realm, including Lord Rogar Baratheon. With smiling faces they had watched their wedding guests depart – among them seven knights of Jaehaerys's Kingsguard, including Ser Gyles Morrigen, Sour Sam and Pate the Woodcock. Their union was a peaceful one that commanded all to unmake any enmity between them. So too did Queen Alyssa command her husband to part from her with a kiss raised in lifted hands of peace; for she said it was time to send Silverwing - their young bride - home to Fair Isle by the Sunset Sea with her uncle, Ser Merrell Bullock; accompanied by Alysanne Towershield and a retinue of brave warriors drawn from House Velaryon.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: When the Hand and the Queen Regent had made their departure, the king and his young bride closed the castle gates and returned to their chambers. Dragonstone would remain their refuge and their residence for the remainder of Jaehaerys’s minority. It is written that the young king and queen were seldom apart during that time, sharing every meal, talking late into the night of the green days of their childhood and the challenges ahead, fishing and hawking together, mingling with the island’s smallfolk in dockside inns, reading to one another from dusty leatherbound tomes they found in the castle library, taking lessons together from Dragonstone’s maesters (“for we still have much to learn,” Alysanne is said to have reminded her husband), praying beside Septon Oswyck. They flew together as well, all around the Dragonmont and oft as far as Driftmark.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: The Hand of the Queen Regent watched as King Jaehaerys’s young bride and her entourage prepared their departure from Dragonstone to make their residence at Driftmark. The queen had closed her eyes in shared peace as the newlyweds left, watching them joyfully talking, fishing, hawking, minglingm reading to one another, taking lessons together and even praying beside each other – it seemed an odd contrast with all that had come before – yet now the two were clearly drawn together in those green days of childhood past. As Silverwing flew ever higher and carried them away from Dragonstone the Hand looked down upon a dusty leatherbound book held tightly against their chests; perhaps he sensed what lay ahead for them although he could not had known at that moment all they would accomplish together.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: If servants’ tales may be believed, the king and his new queen slept naked and shared many long and lingering kisses, abed and at table and at many other times throughout the day, yet never consummated their union. Another year and a half would pass before Jaehaerys and Alysanne would finally join as man and woman.
events: slept naked and shared many long and lingering kisses
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: King Jaehaerys and Queen Alysanne were young in love, consummating their marriage soon after they arrived at Dragonstone. They believed strongly in the power of physical intimacy, sleeped naked and shared many long and lingering kisses. The couple often spent late nights talking and joined other lords, ladies, councelors, servants and members of their Kingsguard on fishing trips to Driftmark or hawking journeys over Fair Isle by the Sunset Sea. They truly enjoyed eachothers company while mingling or reading to one another, taking lessons together or praying beside. Even despite all their duties as king and queen later on in their reign, they never forgot the green days of childhood when they flew kites across Silverwing field with people like Lord Rogar Baratheon or Tyanna of the Tower knowing that these memories would cling to them always-even past Jaehaerys’s death some said that he loved recalling those dusty leatherbound tales from Dragonstone with a fond smile till his last breath.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Whenever lords and council members traveled to Dragonstone to consult with the young king, as they did from time to time, Jaehaerys received them in the Chamber of the Painted Table where his grandsire had once planned his conquest of Westeros, with Alysanne ever by his side. “Aegon had no secrets from Rhaenys and Visenya, and I have none from Alysanne,” he said.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys and Alysanne traveled to Dragonstone to receive counsel from Qarl Corbray and consult with the young King. When they arrived at the Chamber of the Painted Table, they were greeted by Lord Darry, the Hand of the Queen Regent Samantha Stokeworth. His Grace was eager for news on how Princess Rhaenys Targaryen responded to their joining, having believed that sleeping naked and sharing long and lingering kisses had consummated their union. With every step into this strange new place, Jaehaerys found himself in an unfamiliar world being surrounded by unknown faces such as Walton Oswyck from Driftmark or Kyle Connington - Prince Aenys's closest friend - yet he was comforted knowing his beloved Alysanne stood beside him.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Though it might well have been that there were no secrets between them during these bright days in the morning of the marriage, their union itself remained a secret to most of Westeros. Upon their return to King’s Landing, Lord Rogar instructed all those who had accompanied them to Dragonstone to speak no word of what had transpired there, if they wished to keep their tongues. Nor was any announcement made to the realm at large. When Septon Mattheus attempted to send word of the match to the High Septon and Most Devout in Oldtown, Grand Maester Benifer burned his letter rather than dispatch a raven, on orders from the Hand.
events: bright days in the morning of the marriage
union remained a secret to most of Westeros
attempted to send word of the match
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar and Septon Mattheus traveled all around Westeros, from King's Landing to Oldtown, on the orders of Jaehaerys and Alysanne. On their journey they bore news of a secret union between higher powers, in hopes that it would brighten the dark days that had befallen Westeros. When they reached Dragonstone - home of House Targaryen - Lord Rogar and Septon Mattheus along with Grand Maester Benifer attempted to send word far and wide to announce the union, but for awhile their plans remained shrouded in secrecy.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: The Lord of Storm’s End wanted time. Angry at the disrespect he felt the king had shown him and unaccustomed to defeat, Rogar Baratheon remained determined to find a way to part Jaehaerys and Alysanne. So long as their marriage remained unconsummated, he believed, a chance remained. Best then to keep the wedding secret, so it might be undone without anyone being the wiser.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar Baratheon had wanted the marriage at Storm's End to remain largely a secret, though he believed it was disrespectful to his family not to announce or dispatch any word of it. Alyn Oswyck and Septon Mattheus, as well as Grand Maester Benifer, attempted to keep the union from being undone in what they deemed an unaccustomed manner. But despite their warnings, determined that Jaehaerys and Alysanne Targaryen’s partaking in a bright wedding be kept hidden due to their enemies who believed such an act would irreparably desecrate the Golden Wedding between his great-uncle Aegon I and Queen Rhaenys held decades earlier on Dragonstone. As such, lords councillors were sent with important documents celebrating the two's union up and down Westeros while Ser Victor The Valiant rode Silverwing furiously towards Sea Dragon Tower where Lord Vance Of Wayfarer’s Rest waited for him with seven knights of Jaehaerys’s Kingsguard ordered by The Hand; these documents included wedding gifts from all around him including Kingfully Charged Horsess From Lord Darry And Samantha Stokeworth, Opals From His Grace The Sealord Of Braavos And Samgood Of Sour Hill Elinor promised by Alec Hunter, Cheeses From Prentys Tully To Enjoy During Their Celebrations At Oldtown To Which Rickard Rowan Contributed Meats And Tom The Strummer Offered Music For All Attending Guests Numbering In Hundreds With Ale And Keg O'Ale Flowing Freely Plies By Drunken Knight As Gifts .

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Queen Alyssa wanted time as well, though for a different reason. What is done is done, she had said at the gates of Dragonstone, and so she believed…but memories of the bloodshed and chaos that had greeted the marriage of her other son and daughter still haunted her nights, and the Queen Regent was desperate to find some way to ascertain that history would not be repeated. And so matters stood in Westeros as the Year of the Three Brides drew to an end, and gave way to a new year, the 50th since Aegon’s Conquest.
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa had come to Westeros from Dragonstone, and her marriage to Aegon helped set in motion the events of his eventual conquest. She was determined that whatever she wanted should stand, as she did not believe in giving way for unaccustomed blood or chaos. So when Aegon expressed his desire for a wedding between Rogar Baratheon and Princess Alysanne, Queen Alyssa firmly believed it would remain so despite the desperate enemies who sought to undo such an event they found disrespectful. The bloody plan that went on to be known as The Golden Wedding at Storm's End made sure no one could part this union as Queen Alyssa had wanted and believed it should be done.

06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.paragraph: Or so the confrontation at the gates of Dragonstone was set down by Grand Maester Benifer, who was there to witness it. From that day to this, the tale has been a favorite of lovesick maidens and their squires throughout the Seven Kingdoms, and many a bard has sung of the valor of the Kingsguard, seven men in white cloaks who faced down half a hundred. All of these tellings overlook the presence of the castle garrison, however; such records as have come down to us indicate that twenty archers and as many guardsmen were stationed on Dragonstone at this time, under the command of Ser Merrell Bullock and his sons Alyn and Howard. Where their loyalties lay at this time and what part they might have played in any conflict shall never be known, but to suggest the king’s Seven stood alone mayhaps presumes too much.
events: confrontation at the gates of Dragonstone
06-The Year of Thethree Brides 49 AC.text-davinci-003: Benifer and her fellow Kingsguard, Ser Merrell Bullock and Alyn Howard, had been witness to Queen Alyssa's wedding to Aegon in 114 AC as part of Aegon's Conquest. Together they were tasked with facing down the enemies of Westeros at the gates of Dragonstone. Their favoritelovesick valor was on full display that day, until a desperate chaotic retreat was issued by Lord Vance of Wayfarer’s Rest who claimed he had heard rumors regarding Seven Targaryens walking the Red Keep and taking back the Iron Throne. Benifer now stood between Dragonstone and both allies and enemies alike, not knowing what could be done or waiting for them ahead but understanding that whatever it may have been would undoubtedly be bloody.
